awd_titl_txt: Static Liquefaction of Mine Tailings under Non-Standard Stress Paths
awd_abstract_narration:
Static liquefaction of mine tailings has caused numerous recent failures in the United States and around the world. Failure of tailings storage facilities lead to devastating consequences for the environment and civil infrastructure, and lead to loss of human lives. The 2008 Kingston fossil plant failure in Tennessee, an environmental disaster with associated losses on the order of 1.2 billion dollars, is a prime example of the tremendous impact that a tailings storage facility failure can cause. Future failures could have similar devastating consequences for the local and state economies, populations, and industries. Therefore, evaluating the safety of tailings storage facilities is vitally important in any region where mining is active, such as in Colorado, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, and others. Mine tailings are intermediate soil materials often classified as sandy silt to almost pure silt. Conditions for static liquefaction (sudden loss of stability even in the absence of extreme events such as earthquakes) on these materials cannot be evaluated using known engineering procedures. This research will create new knowledge for improving resilient design of tailings storage facilities against static liquefaction and provide insights into creating new design protocols to mitigate potential disasters in the United States and worldwide that are induced by the static liquefaction of mine tailings. The research will also establish an educational and outreach program focused on curriculum development on intermediate soil materials for K-12 students, through STEM centers at Georgia Tech.

Through an integrated experimentally and numerically-based program inspired by recent failures in tailings storage facilities, this research advances liquefaction engineering by investigating (1) the mechanical response of mine tailings under standard and non-standard stress paths, while considering a range of boundary conditions; (2) the conditions for static liquefaction under drained loading conditions, where recent failure events point to a lack of thorough understanding despite the opposite perception among geotechnical engineers; (3) the micromechanics of mine tailings under shearing through image-based experimental techniques; and (4) the effects of micromechanical configurations (i.e. fabric) and induced anisotropy on triggering static liquefaction by using the novel anisotropic critical state theory. Gaining insights into the key parameters that govern the triggering of static liquefaction in mine tailings and developing well-calibrated numerical procedures using the anisotropic critical state theory will transform the ability of geotechnical engineering profession to more effectively evaluate and mitigate the risk of static liquefaction in mine tailings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The recent tailings storage failures (TSF) triggered by mine tailings static liquefaction have caused unprecedented environmental consequences and significant loss of human lives in various countries worldwide. A failure in the U.S. similar to the recent reported failures may have devastating consequences for the U.S. environment, local state economies, and local populations. Therefore, the safety evaluation of TSFs is vitally important in many areas of the U.S. where mining is active, such as Colorado, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, etc. The outcomes of this project have created new knowledge and provided valuable inputs for improving the resilient design and condition assessment of TSFs against static liquefaction. In this manner, this project contributes to improving the sustainability of local populations where mining is an important activity. The project outcomes are also expected to be useful in providing inputs for creating protocols to mitigate potential disasters in the U.S. and internationally caused by mine tailings static liquefaction.

The project outcomes show that fundamentally, mine tailings fit the same critical state soil mechanics-based framework for natural soils, with the key difference of a much larger stress ratio at a critical state and somewhat larger state-dilatancy scaling, both attributed to underlying particle shape and microstructure features, which then affects standard correlations. Moreover, the experimental tests revealed different static liquefaction instability types on mine tailings when sheared under non-standard stress paths and that instability can occur under drained loading if the necessary conditions are met. The observed instabilities are dependent on key mechanical properties such as compressibility, stiffness, dilatancy, the plastic modulus scaling, and the potential of mine tailings for creep. The outcomes also suggest that the anisotropic critical state framework (ACST), traditionally used for sands, is well suited for explaining the response of mine tailings. This is notable as it opens avenues for employing the ACST framework to get insights on the response of other challenging materials (e.g., intermediate soils, ashes, waste materials, biomass). The ACST-based assessments combined with advanced numerical simulations have provided conditions to evaluate static liquefaction under undrained and drained loading for standard and non-standard stress paths. The assessments also suggest that the onset of static liquefaction is sensitive to fabric evolution and its interactions with mechanical properties such as compressibility. The project publications also outline areas of potential future research.

This project has produced several Journal articles and conference papers and it has also provided research, educational, and outreach experiences to Graduate students at the Georgia Institute of Technology. In this manner, this project has also contributed to creating the next generation of tailings engineers.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Jorge Macedo
